title: Finding Probabilities from a $z$-table
question_text:
According to the $z$-table, find $p(z < -1.26)$.
Reference your AP Statistics Exam materials
solution:
The $z$-table shows the area to the left of the given $z$-score or the probability of $z < (\text{the given $z$-score})$. If we are looking for $p(z < -1.26)$, go down the left column of the $z$-table until you reach $-1.2$ then follow this row across until it intersects with the column labeled $.06$. Together this represents the $z$-score of $-1.26$ and the entry you will find in this cell $(0.1038)$ gives $p(z < -1.26)$.

Note: you can also find this answer using the normalcdf function on your TI83/84 graphing calculator. The syntax is: normalcdf(lower bound, upper bound, mean, standard deviation).

In this case:

Enter *2nd, DISTR *
Choose normalcdf
Enter -10^99, -1.26, 0, 1

The calculator will return the value of about $0.1038$.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'B' is incorrect. It represents $p(z < -1.25)$ and can be found by counting over on the $z$-table six spaces from $z = -1.2$. This ignores the value of $z = -1.20$ and considers it to be $z = -1.21$. Also, keep in mind that we can only find probabilities associated with $z$-scores that are strictly between $z = -1.25$ and $z = -1.26$ using the calculator.

Choice 'C' is incorrect. It represents $p(z < -1.20)$.

Choice 'D' is incorrect. It represents $p(z < 1.20)$.

Choice 'E' is incorrect. It represents $p(z < 1.26)$.
